message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Consistent Individual Behavioral Variation: What Do We Know and Where Are We Going?
Paper Abstract: The study of individual behavioral variation, sometimes called animal personalities or behavioral types, is now a well-established area of research in behavioral ecology and evolution. Considerable theoretical work has developed predictions about its ecological and evolutionary causes and consequences, and studies testing these theories continue to grow. Here, we synthesize the current empirical work to shed light on which theories are well supported and which need further refinement. We find that the major frameworks explaining the existence of individual behavioral variation, the pace-of-life syndrome hypothesis and state-dependent feedbacks models, have mixed support. The consequences of individual behavioral variation are well studied at the individual level but less is known about consequences at higher levels such as among species and communities. The focus of this review is to reevaluate and reestablish the foundation of individual behavioral variation research: What do we know? What questions remain? And where are we going next?
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Animal personality behavior"

Links: [{"title":"Personality in animals - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_in_animals"},{"title":"The Animal in You - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Animal_in_You"},{"title":"Samuel D. Gosling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_D._Gosling"},{"title":"Comparative psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparative_psychology"},{"title":"Species-typical behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Species-typical_behavior"},{"title":"Animal behaviour - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_behaviour"},{"title":"Dog behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dog_behavior"},{"title":"Ethology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethology"},{"title":"Behavioral syndrome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_syndrome"},{"title":"Animal stereotype - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_stereotype"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about animal personality and behavior:

## What is Animal Personality?

Animal personality is defined as individual differences in behavior that are consistent across time and ecological context.(no content)Animal personality traits are measurable and are described in over 100 species.

## Common Personality Traits

Neuroticism, agreeableness and extraversion are the most commonly found personality traits among measured animals.(no content)For example, chimpanzees show emotional stability, agreeableness and surgency, audiovisual reactivity, affect-extraversion, excitability-agitation, aggression, affinity and social play.

## Behavioral Syndromes

In behavioral ecology, a behavioral syndrome is a correlated suite of behavioral traits, often measured across multiple contexts.(no content)For example, the lizards Eulamprus heatwolei show a behavioral syndrome with two behavioral types, with a correlated relationship between how territorial an individual is, how likely they are to explore their environment, and what strategy they use to avoid predation.

## Determining Behavior

Behavior is determined by three major factors, namely inborn instincts, learning, and environmental factors.

## Research and Study

Personality in animals has been investigated across a variety of different scientific fields including agricultural science, animal behaviour, anthropology, psychology, veterinary medicine, and zoology.(no content)Research on animal personality variation has been burgeoning since the mid 1990s.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Evolution biology"

Links: [{"title":"Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution"},{"title":"Society for Molecular Biology and Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_for_Molecular_Biology_and_Evolution"},{"title":"Molecular Biology and Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molecular_Biology_and_Evolution"},{"title":"Nothing in Biology Makes Sense Except in the Light of Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nothing_in_Biology_Makes_Sense_Except_in_the_Light_of_Evolution"},{"title":"Evolution of biological complexity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_of_biological_complexity"},{"title":"Evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_biology"},{"title":"Ecology and evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecology_and_evolutionary_biology"},{"title":"Contingency (evolutionary biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contingency_(evolutionary_biology)"},{"title":"Biological Evolution: Facts and Theories - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_Evolution:_Facts_and_Theories"},{"title":"Category:Biological evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Biological_evolution"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of evolution in biology:

## What is Evolution?

Evolution is the change in the heritable characteristics of biological populations over successive generations.(no content)It occurs when evolutionary processes such as genetic drift and natural selection act on genetic variation, resulting in certain characteristics becoming more or less common within a population over successive generations.

## The Field of Evolutionary Biology

Evolutionary biology is a subfield of biology that analyzes the four mechanisms of evolution: natural selection, mutation, genetic drift, and gene flow.(no content)The purpose of evolutionary biology is to observe the diversity of life on Earth.

## Historical Development

The scientific theory of evolution by natural selection was conceived independently by two British naturalists, Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace, in the mid-19th century as an explanation for why organisms are adapted to their physical and biological environments.(no content)Evolutionary biology, as an academic discipline in its own right, emerged during the period of the modern synthesis in the 1930s and 1940s.

## Mechanisms and Outcomes

The process of evolution has given rise to biodiversity at every level of biological organisation.(no content)Evolution is the central unifying concept in biology.(no content)These processes are studied at different levels of complexity from observing features in living or fossilized species to analyzing DNA genomic sequencing between species.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the web search results, here's information about state dependent feedback:

## Overview

Feedback is extensively used in control theory, using a variety of methods including state space (controls), full state feedback, and so forth. State dependent feedback refers to a control strategy where the feedback control signal depends on the current state of the system.

## Key Concept

In control theory, in closed loop control, the control action from the controller is dependent on the process output. More specifically for state-based approaches, a closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

## Application in State Space

A common method for feedback is to multiply the output by a matrix K and setting this as the input to the system. This is a fundamental approach in state-dependent feedback control where the feedback gain matrix K is applied to the system state to generate the control input.

## Control Design

Comparing the terms of this equation with those of the desired characteristic equation yields the values of the feedback matrix which force the closed-loop eigenvalues to the pole locations specified by the desired characteristic equation. This demonstrates how state-dependent feedback is designed to achieve desired system performance by appropriately choosing the feedback gains.

The term "state dependent" emphasizes that the control action is a function of the current state variables of the system, allowing for more sophisticated and adaptive control compared to simple open-loop approaches.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of behavioral ecology:

## Definition

Behavioral ecology is the study of the evolutionary basis for animal behavior due to ecological pressures. More broadly, it is a major subfield of both ecology and evolutionary biology that incorporates both ecological and evolutionary principles to analyze the ways in which animal behavior has evolved, and the ways in which animals use behavior to solve social and ecological problems.

## Historical Development

Behavioral ecology emerged from ethology after Niko Tinbergen outlined four questions to address when studying animal behaviors: what are the proximate causes, ontogeny, survival value, and phylogeny of a behavior?

## Key Concepts

A central principle in behavioral ecology is the concept of adaptive significance. If an organism has a trait that provides a selective advantage in its environment, then natural selection favors it, with adaptive significance referring to the expression of a trait that affects fitness, measured by an individual's reproductive success.

## Areas of Study

The field includes the study of the evolution of aggression, mating behavior, parental care, communication, and the complexities of living in groups and families. Major research areas also cover family interactions and conflicts, which can be broken down into three general types: sexual (male–female) conflict, parent–offspring conflict, and sibling conflict.

Human behavioral ecology also applies these same principles. Human behavioral ecology applies the principles of evolutionary theory and optimization to the study of human behavioral and cultural diversity, and examines the adaptive design of traits, behaviors, and life histories of humans in an ecological context.

Web search results for query: "Individual behavior variation animal personality"

Links: [{"title":"Personality in animals - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_in_animals"},{"title":"Behavioral syndrome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_syndrome"},{"title":"Adaptive behavior (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_behavior_(ecology)"},{"title":"Behavioral plasticity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_plasticity"},{"title":"Behavioural genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychogenomics"},{"title":"Species-typical behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Species-typical_behavior"},{"title":"Comparative psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparative_psychology"},{"title":"Animal behaviour - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_behavior"},{"title":"Biological basis of personality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_basis_of_personality"},{"title":"The Animal in You - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Animal_in_You"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about individual behavior variation and animal personality:

## Definition and Core Concept

Animal personality is defined as individual differences in behaviour that are consistent across time and ecological context.(no content)Animal personality traits are measurable and are described in over 100 species.

## Scale of Behavioral Variation

In a meta-analysis of published, peer-reviewed repeatability estimates, reviewers found that approximately 35% of behavioural variation among individuals could be attributed to individual differences. This suggests that while individual personality plays a role, other factors like environmental conditions also significantly influence behavior.

## Terminology and Research

Many researchers are critical of the lack of consistency in terminology surrounding animal personality, with terms like temperament, behavioral syndrome, disposition and animal personality sometimes used interchangeably.(no content)Research on animal personality variation has been burgeoning since the mid 1990s.

## Behavioral Syndromes

In behavioral ecology, a behavioral syndrome is a correlated suite of behavioral traits, often measured across multiple contexts, where the suite of traits that are correlated at the population or species level is considered the behavioral syndrome, while the phenotype the individual shows is their behavioral type.

## Evolutionary Significance

Personality in animals can affect the way individuals interact with their environment and with each other which can affect the relative fitness of individuals, and therefore personality can influence selection.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Personality in animals - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_in_animals"},{"title":"Behavioral syndrome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_syndrome"},{"title":"Adaptive behavior (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_behavior_(ecology)"},{"title":"Behavioral plasticity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_plasticity"},{"title":"Behavioural genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychogenomics"},{"title":"Species-typical behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Species-typical_behavior"},{"title":"Comparative psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparative_psychology"},{"title":"Animal behaviour - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_behavior"},{"title":"Biological basis of personality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_basis_of_personality"},{"title":"The Animal in You - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Animal_in_You"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about individual behavior variation and animal personality:

## Definition and Core Concept

Animal personality is defined as individual differences in behaviour that are consistent across time and ecological context.(no content)Animal personality traits are measurable and are described in over 100 species.

## Scale of Behavioral Variation

In a meta-analysis of published, peer-reviewed repeatability estimates, reviewers found that approximately 35% of behavioural variation among individuals could be attributed to individual differences. This suggests that while individual personality plays a role, other factors like environmental conditions also significantly influence behavior.

## Terminology and Research

Many researchers are critical of the lack of consistency in terminology surrounding animal personality, with terms like temperament, behavioral syndrome, disposition and animal personality sometimes used interchangeably.(no content)Research on animal personality variation has been burgeoning since the mid 1990s.

## Behavioral Syndromes

In behavioral ecology, a behavioral syndrome is a correlated suite of behavioral traits, often measured across multiple contexts, where the suite of traits that are correlated at the population or species level is considered the behavioral syndrome, while the phenotype the individual shows is their behavioral type.

## Evolutionary Significance

Personality in animals can affect the way individuals interact with their environment and with each other which can affect the relative fitness of individuals, and therefore personality can influence selection.

Links: [{"title":"Behavioral syndrome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_syndrome"},{"title":"Emotional and behavioral disorders - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotional_and_behavioral_disorders"},{"title":"List of mental disorders - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mental_disorders"},{"title":"Behavioral neurology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_neurology"},{"title":"Borderline personality disorder - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Borderline_personality_disorder"},{"title":"Smith–Magenis syndrome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smith–Magenis_syndrome"},{"title":"Dopamine dysregulation syndrome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hedonistic_homeostatic_dysregulation"},{"title":"Beck–Fahrner syndrome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beck%E2%80%93Fahrner_syndrome"},{"title":"Acute behavioural disturbance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acute_behavioural_disturbance"},{"title":"Williams syndrome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Williams_syndrome"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about behavioral syndromes:

## Definition and Overview

In behavioral ecology, a behavioral syndrome is a correlated suite of behavioral traits, often (but not always) measured across multiple contexts.(no content)The suite of traits that are correlated at the population or species level is considered the behavioral syndrome, while the phenotype of the behavioral syndrome an individual shows is their behavioral type.

## Example in Nature

The lizards Eulamprus heatwolei show a behavioral syndrome with two behavioral types, with a correlated relationship between how territorial an individual is, how likely they are to explore their environment, and what strategy they use to avoid predation.(no content)This behavioral syndrome has also been shown to influence the mating system of this species; territorial males are more likely to sire offspring with territorial females, and larger territorial males compete less with other males for mates.

## Historical Context

Behavioral syndrome is a term that originated in the psychology literature and was originally used to describe human behavioral disorders, including nervous and stereotypical behaviors.(no content)The term was adopted by behavioral ecologists and re-defined in 2004, and has become a popular field of study, both empirically and theoretically.

## Evolutionary Significance

The nature of behavioral syndromes implies that there can be constraints on the behavior of an individual, which can lead to non-optimal behavior that has long been puzzling to behavioral ecologists (e.g., attacking a predator when fleeing is a better option).

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis. Here's a summary:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey (literature review)

**Triples Extracted (5 total):**

1. **Personality in animals** - A core synonym for individual behavioral variation discussed throughout the paper
2. **Behavioral ecology** - The main disciplinary framework for studying individual behavioral variation
3. **Evolution** - Key concept examining ecological and evolutionary causes of behavioral variation
4. **Behavioral syndrome** - Related framework for understanding correlated behavioral traits
5. **Animal behaviour** - The fundamental subject matter of the research

**Validation Status:** All checks passed successfully! ✅

The paper is correctly classified as a survey since it synthesizes existing empirical work on individual behavioral variation, reviews theoretical frameworks (like the pace-of-life syndrome hypothesis and state-dependent feedbacks models), and evaluates current knowledge in the field. All triples are concept-type entities with "uses" relations, reflecting that this is a literature review that builds on existing theoretical and empirical foundations.

Sources:
- [Personality in animals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_in_animals)
- [Behavioral ecology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_ecology)
- [Evolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution)
- [Behavioral syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_syndrome)
- [Animal behaviour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_behaviour)
